<p>On February 27, 2009, O'Neal scored 45 points and grabbed 11 rebounds, his 49th career 40-point game, beating the <a href="/wiki/Toronto_Raptors" title="Toronto Raptors">Toronto Raptors</a> 133–113.
</p><p>In a matchup against Orlando on March 3, 2009, O'Neal was outscored by Magic center <a href="/wiki/Dwight_Howard" title="Dwight Howard">Dwight Howard</a>, 21–19. "I'm really too old to be trying to outscore 18-year-olds", O'Neal said, referring to the then 23-year-old Howard. "It's not really my role anymore." O'Neal was double-teamed most of the night. "I like to play people one-on-one. My whole career I had to play people one-on-one. Never once had to double or ask for a double. But it's cool", said O'Neal. During the game, O'Neal flopped against Howard. Magic coach <a href="/wiki/Stan_Van_Gundy" title="Stan Van Gundy">Stan Van Gundy</a>, who had coached O'Neal with the Heat, was "very disappointed cause [O'Neal] knows what it's like. Let's stand up and play like men, and I think our guy did that tonight."<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">&#91;100&#93;</a></sup> O'Neal responded, "Flopping is playing like that your whole career. I was trying to take the charge, trying to get a call. It probably was a flop, but flopping is the wrong use of words. Flopping would describe his coaching."<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">&#91;101&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mark_Madsen_(basketball)" title="Mark Madsen (basketball)">Mark Madsen</a>, a Lakers teammate of O'Neal's for three years, found it amusing since "everyone in the league tries to flop on Shaq and Shaq never flops back."<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">&#91;102&#93;</a></sup> In a 2006 interview in <i>TIME</i>, O'Neal said if he were NBA commissioner, he would "Make a guy have to beat a guy—not flop and get calls and be nice to the referees and kiss ass."<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">&#91;103&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On March 6, O'Neal talked about the upcoming game against the Rockets and <a href="/wiki/Yao_Ming" title="Yao Ming">Yao Ming</a>. "It's not going to be man-on-man, so don't even try that," says O'Neal with an incredulous laugh. "They're going to double and triple me like everybody else ... I rarely get to play [Yao] one-on-one ... But when I play him (on defense), it's just going to be me down there. So don't try to make it a Yao versus Shaq thing, when it's Shaq versus four other guys."<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">&#91;104&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/2009_NBA_Playoffs" class="mw-redirect" title="2009 NBA Playoffs">2009 NBA Playoffs</a> was also the first time since O'Neal's rookie season in <a href="/wiki/1992%E2%80%9393_NBA_season" title="1992–93 NBA season">1992–93</a> that he did not participate in the playoffs. He was named as a member of the All-NBA Third Team. The Suns notified O'Neal he might be traded to cut costs.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">&#91;105&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Cleveland_Cavaliers_.282009.E2.80.932010.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Cleveland_Cavaliers_(2009–2010)">Cleveland Cavaliers (2009–2010)</span></h3>
<p>On June 25, 2009, O'Neal was traded to the <a href="/wiki/Cleveland_Cavaliers" title="Cleveland Cavaliers">Cleveland Cavaliers</a> for <a href="/wiki/Aleksandar_Pavlovi%C4%87" title="Aleksandar Pavlović">Sasha Pavlovic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ben_Wallace_(basketball)" title="Ben Wallace (basketball)">Ben Wallace</a>, $500,000, and a 2010 second-round draft pick.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">&#91;106&#93;</a></sup> Upon arriving in Cleveland, O'Neal said, "My motto is very simple: Win a Ring for the King", referring to <a href="/wiki/LeBron_James" title="LeBron James">LeBron James</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">&#91;107&#93;</a></sup> James was the leader of the team, and O'Neal deferred to him.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">&#91;108&#93;</a></sup> On February 25, 2010, O'Neal suffered a severe right thumb injury while attempting to go up for a shot against <a href="/wiki/Glen_Davis_(basketball)" title="Glen Davis (basketball)">Glen Davis</a> of the Boston Celtics.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">&#91;109&#93;</a></sup> He had surgery on the thumb on March 1 and returned to play in time for the <a href="/wiki/2010_NBA_Playoffs" class="mw-redirect" title="2010 NBA Playoffs">first round of the playoffs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">&#91;110&#93;</a></sup> After defeating the <a href="/wiki/Chicago_Bulls" title="Chicago Bulls">Chicago Bulls</a> in the first round, the Cavaliers went on to lose to the Boston Celtics in the second round. In September 2016, O'Neal said: "When I was in Cleveland, we were in first place. Big Baby [Glen Davis] breaks my hand and I had to sit out five weeks late in the year. I come back finally in the first round of the playoffs, and we lost to Boston in the second round. I was upset. I know for a fact if I was healthy, we would have gotten it done that year and won a ring."<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">&#91;111&#93;</a></sup> O'Neal averaged career lows in almost every major statistical category during the 2009–10 season, taking on a much less significant role than in previous years.
</p>
<h3><span id="Boston_Celtics_.282010.E2.80.932011.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Boston_Celtics_(2010–2011)">Boston Celtics (2010–2011)</span></h3>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Shaquille_O%27Neal.JPG" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Shaquille_O%27Neal.JPG/240px-Shaquille_O%27Neal.JPG" decoding="async" width="240" height="180" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Shaquille_O%27Neal.JPG/360px-Shaquille_O%27Neal.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Shaquille_O%27Neal.JPG/480px-Shaquille_O%27Neal.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1200" /></a><figcaption>O'Neal finished his career with the <a href="/wiki/Boston_Celtics" title="Boston Celtics">Boston Celtics</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Upon hearing Bryant comment that he had more rings than O'Neal, <a href="/wiki/Wycliffe_Grousbeck" class="mw-redirect" title="Wycliffe Grousbeck">Wyc Grousbeck</a>, principal owner of the Celtics, saw an opportunity to acquire O'Neal.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup> Celtics coach <a href="/wiki/Doc_Rivers" title="Doc Rivers">Doc Rivers</a> agreed to the signing on the condition that O'Neal would not receive preferential treatment, nor could he cause any locker room problems like in Los Angeles or Miami.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">&#91;113&#93;</a></sup> On August 4, 2010, the Celtics announced that they had signed O'Neal.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">&#91;114&#93;</a></sup> The contract was for two years at the veteran minimum salary for a total contract value of $2.8&#160;million.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">&#91;115&#93;</a></sup> O'Neal wanted the larger <a href="/wiki/Mid-level_exception" class="mw-redirect" title="Mid-level exception">mid-level exception</a> contract, but the Celtics chose instead to give it to <a href="/wiki/Jermaine_O%27Neal" title="Jermaine O&#39;Neal">Jermaine O'Neal</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">&#91;116&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Atlanta_Hawks" title="Atlanta Hawks">Atlanta Hawks</a> and the Dallas Mavericks also expressed interest but had stalled on O'Neal's salary demands.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">&#91;117&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">&#91;118&#93;</a></sup> He was introduced by the Celtics on August 10, 2010, and chose the number 36.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">&#91;119&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>O'Neal said he did not "compete with little guys who run around dominating the ball, throwing up 30 shots a night—like D–Wade, Kobe." O'Neal added that he was only competing against Duncan: "If Tim Duncan gets five rings, then that gives some writer the chance to say 'Duncan is the best,' and I can't have that."<sup id="cite_ref-macmullan_20100927_120-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-macmullan_20100927-120">&#91;120&#93;</a></sup> Publicly, he insisted he did not care whether he started or substituted for the Celtics, but expected to be part of the second unit.<sup id="cite_ref-macmullan_20100927_120-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-macmullan_20100927-120">&#91;120&#93;</a></sup> Privately, he wanted to start, but kept it to himself.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">&#91;121&#93;</a></sup> O'Neal missed games throughout the season due to an assortment of ailments to his right leg<sup id="cite_ref-may_122-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-may-122">&#91;122&#93;</a></sup> including knee,<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">&#91;123&#93;</a></sup> calf,<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">&#91;124&#93;</a></sup> hip,<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">&#91;125&#93;</a></sup> and Achilles injuries.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">&#91;126&#93;</a></sup> The Celtics traded away center <a href="/wiki/Kendrick_Perkins" title="Kendrick Perkins">Kendrick Perkins</a> in February partially due to the expectation that O'Neal would return to fill Perkins' role. The Celtics were 33–10 in games Perkins had missed during the year due to injury,<sup id="cite_ref-may_122-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-may-122">&#91;122&#93;</a></sup> and they were 19–3 in games that O'Neal played over 20&#160;minutes.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">&#91;127&#93;</a></sup> After requesting a <a href="/wiki/Cortisone" title="Cortisone">cortisone</a> shot, O'Neal returned April 3 after missing 27&#160;games due to his Achilles; he played only five minutes due to a strained right calf.<sup id="cite_ref-may_122-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-may-122">&#91;122&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">&#91;128&#93;</a></sup> It was the last regular season game he would play that year.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">&#91;129&#93;</a></sup> O'Neal missed the first round of the <a href="/wiki/2011_NBA_Playoffs" class="mw-redirect" title="2011 NBA Playoffs">2011 playoffs</a>. He insisted on more cortisone shots and returned in the second round, but he was limited to 12&#160;minutes in two games as the Heat eliminated the Celtics from the playoffs.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">&#91;130&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">&#91;131&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On June 1, 2011, O'Neal announced his retirement via social media.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">&#91;132&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-giles_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-giles-133">&#91;133&#93;</a></sup> On a short video on Twitter, O'Neal tweeted, "We did it. Nineteen years, baby. I want to thank you very much. That's why I'm telling you first. I'm about to retire. Love you. Talk to you soon." On June 3, 2011, O'Neal held a press conference at his home in Orlando to officially announce his retirement.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">&#91;134&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="National_team_career">National team career</span></h2>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Shaquille_v_Spain_1994.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Shaquille_v_Spain_1994.jpg/170px-Shaquille_v_Spain_1994.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="293" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Shaquille_v_Spain_1994.jpg/255px-Shaquille_v_Spain_1994.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Shaquille_v_Spain_1994.jpg/340px-Shaquille_v_Spain_1994.jpg 2x" data-file-width="508" data-file-height="877" /></a><figcaption>O'Neal with the US national team at the <a href="/wiki/1994_FIBA_World_Championship" title="1994 FIBA World Championship">1994 FIBA World Championship</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>While in college, O'Neal was considered for the <a href="/wiki/1992_United_States_men%27s_Olympic_basketball_team" title="1992 United States men&#39;s Olympic basketball team">Dream Team</a> to fill the college spot, but it eventually went to future teammate <a href="/wiki/Christian_Laettner" title="Christian Laettner">Christian Laettner</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">&#91;135&#93;</a></sup> His national team career began in the <a href="/wiki/1994_FIBA_World_Championship" title="1994 FIBA World Championship">1994 FIBA World Championship</a> in which he was named <a href="/wiki/FIBA_World_Cup_MVP" class="mw-redirect" title="FIBA World Cup MVP">MVP of the Tournament</a>. While he led the <a href="/wiki/United_States_men%27s_national_basketball_team#Olympics" title="United States men&#39;s national basketball team">Dream Team II</a> to the gold medal with an 8–0 record, O'Neal averaged 18 points and 8.5 rebounds and recorded two double-doubles. In four games, he scored more than 20 points. Before 2010, he was the last active American player to have a gold from the <a href="/wiki/FIBA_World_Cup" class="mw-redirect" title="FIBA World Cup">FIBA World Cup</a>.
</p><p>He was one of two players (the other being <a href="/wiki/Reggie_Miller" title="Reggie Miller">Reggie Miller</a>) from the 1994 roster to be also named to the <a href="/wiki/1996_United_States_men%27s_Olympic_basketball_team" title="1996 United States men&#39;s Olympic basketball team">Dream Team III</a>. Due to more star-power, he rotated with <a href="/wiki/Hakeem_Olajuwon" title="Hakeem Olajuwon">Hakeem Olajuwon</a> and <a href="/wiki/David_Robinson_(basketball)" class="mw-redirect" title="David Robinson (basketball)">David Robinson</a> and started 3 games. He averaged 9.3 points and 5.3 rebounds with 8 total blocks. Again, a perfect 8–0 record landed him another gold medal at the <a href="/wiki/Basketball_at_the_1996_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_tournament" title="Basketball at the 1996 Summer Olympics – Men&#39;s tournament">1996 Olympics</a> in Atlanta. O'Neal was upset that coach <a href="/wiki/Lenny_Wilkens" title="Lenny Wilkens">Lenny Wilkens</a> played Robinson more minutes in the final game; Wilkens previously explained to O'Neal that it would probably be Robinson's last Olympics.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">&#91;136&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>After his 1996 experience, he declined to play in international competition. He was angered by being overlooked for the <a href="/wiki/FIBA_Americas_Championship_1999" class="mw-redirect" title="FIBA Americas Championship 1999">1999 FIBA AmeriCup</a> squad, saying it was a "lack of respect".<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">&#91;137&#93;</a></sup> He forwent an opportunity to participate in the <a href="/wiki/Basketball_at_the_2000_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_tournament" title="Basketball at the 2000 Summer Olympics – Men&#39;s tournament">2000 Olympics</a>, explaining that two gold medals were enough.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">&#91;138&#93;</a></sup> O'Neal also chose not to play in the <a href="/wiki/2002_FIBA_World_Championship" title="2002 FIBA World Championship">2002 FIBA World Championship</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">&#91;139&#93;</a></sup> He rejected an offer to play in the <a href="/wiki/Basketball_at_the_2004_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_tournament" title="Basketball at the 2004 Summer Olympics – Men&#39;s tournament">2004 Olympics</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">&#91;140&#93;</a></sup> and although he was initially interested in being named for 2006–2008 US preliminary roster,<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">&#91;141&#93;</a></sup> he eventually declined the invitation.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">&#91;142&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Player_profile">Player profile</span></h2>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Shaquille_O%27Neal_Free_Throw.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Shaquille_O%27Neal_Free_Throw.jpg/170px-Shaquille_O%27Neal_Free_Throw.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="254" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Shaquille_O%27Neal_Free_Throw.jpg/255px-Shaquille_O%27Neal_Free_Throw.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Shaquille_O%27Neal_Free_Throw.jpg/340px-Shaquille_O%27Neal_Free_Throw.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2199" data-file-height="3288" /></a><figcaption>O'Neal's free throw shooting was regarded as one of his major weaknesses.</figcaption></figure>
<p>O'Neal established himself as an overpowering low post presence, putting up career averages of 23.7 points on .582 field goal accuracy, 10.9 rebounds and 2.3 blocks per game.
</p><p>At 7&#160;ft 1&#160;in (2.16&#160;m), 330&#160;lb (150&#160;kg)<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">&#91;143&#93;</a></sup> and U.S. <a href="/wiki/Shoe_size" title="Shoe size">shoe size</a> 23,<sup id="cite_ref-nbabio_65-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nbabio-65">&#91;65&#93;</a></sup> he became famous for his physical stature. His physical frame gave him a power advantage over most opponents. On two occasions during his first season in the NBA, his powerful dunks <a href="/wiki/Backboard_shattering" title="Backboard shattering">broke the steel backboard supports</a>, prompting the league to increase the brace strength and stability of the backboards for the following 1993–94 season.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">&#91;144&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>O'Neal's "<a href="/wiki/Drop_step" class="mw-redirect" title="Drop step">drop step</a>", (called the "Black Tornado" by O'Neal) in which he posted up a defender, turned around and, using his elbows for leverage, powered past him for a very high-percentage <a href="/wiki/Slam_dunk" title="Slam dunk">slam dunk</a>, proved an effective offensive weapon. In addition, O'Neal frequently used a right-handed <a href="/wiki/Hook_shot" title="Hook shot">jump hook</a> shot to score near the basket. The ability to dunk contributed to his career field goal accuracy of .582, second only to <a href="/wiki/Artis_Gilmore" title="Artis Gilmore">Artis Gilmore</a> as the highest field goal percentage of all time.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">&#91;145&#93;</a></sup> He led the NBA in field goal percentage 10 times, breaking <a href="/wiki/Wilt_Chamberlain" title="Wilt Chamberlain">Wilt Chamberlain</a>'s record of nine.<sup id="cite_ref-nbabio_65-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nbabio-65">&#91;65&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Opposing teams often used up many fouls on O'Neal, reducing the playing time of their own big men. O'Neal's imposing physical presence inside the <a href="/wiki/Key_(basketball)" title="Key (basketball)">paint</a> caused dramatic changes in many teams' offensive and defensive strategies.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">&#91;146&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>O'Neal's primary weakness was his <a href="/wiki/Free_throw" title="Free throw">free throw</a> shooting, with a career average of 52.7%. He once missed all 11 of his free throw attempts in a game against the <a href="/wiki/Seattle_SuperSonics" title="Seattle SuperSonics">Seattle SuperSonics</a> on December 8, 2000, a record.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">&#91;147&#93;</a></sup> O'Neal believes his free throw woes were a mental issue, as he often shot 80&#160;percent in practice.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">&#91;148&#93;</a></sup> In hope of exploiting O'Neal's poor foul shooting, opponents often committed intentional fouls against him, a tactic known as "<a href="/wiki/Hack-a-Shaq" title="Hack-a-Shaq">Hack-a-Shaq</a>". O'Neal was the third-ranked player all-time in free throws taken,<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">&#91;149&#93;</a></sup> having attempted 11,252 free-throws in 1,207 games up to and including the 2010–11 season. On December 25, 2008, O'Neal missed his 5,000th free throw, becoming the second player in NBA history to do so, along with Chamberlain.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">&#91;150&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>O'Neal only made one three-point shot during his entire career. He made the shot during the 1995–96 NBA season with the Orlando Magic. His career three-point-shot record is 1 for 22 (a 4.5% career percentage).
</p><p>O'Neal was a capable defender, named three times to the All-NBA Second Defensive Team. His presence intimidated opposing players shooting near the basket, and he averaged 2.3 blocked shots per game over the course of his career.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">&#91;151&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Phil Jackson believed O'Neal underachieved in his career, saying he "could and should have been the MVP player for 10 consecutive seasons."<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">&#91;152&#93;</a></sup> In 2022, to commemorate the NBA's 75th Anniversary <i><a href="/wiki/The_Athletic" title="The Athletic">The Athletic</a></i> ranked their top 75 players of all time, and named O'Neal as the 8th greatest player in NBA history.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">&#91;153&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Lakers#Retired_numbers" title="Los Angeles Lakers">The Lakers retired</a> his No. 34 jersey on April 2, 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">&#91;154&#93;</a></sup> On February 26, 2016, the Miami Heat announced that it would retire O'Neal's No. 32 jersey during the 2016–17 season, making O'Neal one of just 32 athletes in American professional sports history to have their jersey retired by multiple teams.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">&#91;155&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">&#91;156&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Miami_Heat#Retired_numbers" title="Miami Heat">The Heat eventually retired</a> his jersey on December 22, 2016, during halftime of a game against his former team, the <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Lakers" title="Los Angeles Lakers">Los Angeles Lakers</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Off_the_court">Off the court</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media_personality">Media personality</span></h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Shaquille_O%27Neal_1998.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Shaquille_O%27Neal_1998.jpg/220px-Shaquille_O%27Neal_1998.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="263" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Shaquille_O%27Neal_1998.jpg/330px-Shaquille_O%27Neal_1998.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Shaquille_O%27Neal_1998.jpg/440px-Shaquille_O%27Neal_1998.jpg 2x" data-file-width="990" data-file-height="1182" /></a><figcaption>O'Neal in 1998</figcaption></figure>
<p>O'Neal called himself "The Big Aristotle" and "Hobo Master" for his composure and insights during interviews. Journalists and others gave O'Neal several nicknames, including "Shaq", "The Diesel", "<a href="/wiki/Shaq_Fu" title="Shaq Fu">Shaq Fu</a>", "The Big Daddy", "<a href="/wiki/Superman" title="Superman">Superman</a>", "The Big <a href="/wiki/Agave" title="Agave">Agave</a>", "The Big <a href="/wiki/Cactus" title="Cactus">Cactus</a>", "The Big Shaqtus", "The Big <a href="/wiki/Galactus" title="Galactus">Galactus</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Wilt_Chamberlain" title="Wilt Chamberlain">Wilt Chamberneezy</a>", "The Big <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Baryshnikov" title="Mikhail Baryshnikov">Baryshnikov</a>", "The Real Deal", "The Big <a href="/wiki/Shamrock" title="Shamrock">Shamrock</a>", "The Big <a href="/wiki/Leprechaun" title="Leprechaun">Leprechaun</a>", "Shaqovic",<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">&#91;157&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">&#91;158&#93;</a></sup> and "The Big Conductor".<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">&#91;159&#93;</a></sup> Although he was a favorite interviewee of the press, O'Neal was sensitive and often went weeks without speaking.<sup id="cite_ref-heisler_06012011_160-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-heisler_06012011-160">&#91;160&#93;</a></sup> When he did not want to speak with the press, he employed an interview technique whereby, sitting in front of his cubicle, he would murmur in his low-pitched voice.<sup id="cite_ref-heisler_06012011_160-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-heisler_06012011-160">&#91;160&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">&#91;161&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>During the 2000 <a href="/wiki/Screen_Actors_Guild" title="Screen Actors Guild">Screen Actors Guild</a> strike, O'Neal performed in a commercial for <a href="/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Company" title="The Walt Disney Company">Disney</a>. O'Neal was fined by the union for crossing the <a href="/wiki/Picketing_(protest)" class="mw-redirect" title="Picketing (protest)">picket line</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">&#91;162&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">&#91;163&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>O'Neal's humorous and sometimes incendiary comments fueled the <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Lakers" title="Los Angeles Lakers">Los Angeles Lakers</a>' long-standing rivalry with the <a href="/wiki/Sacramento_Kings" title="Sacramento Kings">Sacramento Kings</a>; O'Neal frequently referred to the Sacramento team as the "Queens".<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">&#91;164&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">&#91;165&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">&#91;166&#93;</a></sup> During the 2002 victory parade, O'Neal declared that Sacramento would never be the capital of California,<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">&#91;167&#93;</a></sup> after the Lakers beat the Kings in a tough seven-game series en route to its third championship with O'Neal.
</p><p>He also received media flak for <a href="/wiki/Ching_chong" title="Ching chong">mocking Chinese people</a> when interviewed about newcomer center <a href="/wiki/Yao_Ming" title="Yao Ming">Yao Ming</a>. O'Neal told a reporter, "you tell Yao Ming, ching chong yang, wah, ah so."<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">&#91;168&#93;</a></sup> O'Neal later said it was <a href="/wiki/Locker_room" class="mw-redirect" title="Locker room">locker room</a> humor and he meant no offense. Yao believed that O'Neal was joking, but he said many Asians wouldn't see the humor.<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">&#91;169&#93;</a></sup> Yao joked, "Chinese is hard to learn. I had trouble with it when I was little."<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">&#91;170&#93;</a></sup> O'Neal later expressed regret for the way he treated Yao early in his career.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">&#91;171&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>During the 2005 NBA playoffs, O'Neal compared his poor play to <a href="/wiki/Erick_Dampier" title="Erick Dampier">Erick Dampier</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">&#91;172&#93;</a></sup> a <a href="/wiki/Dallas_Mavericks" title="Dallas Mavericks">Dallas Mavericks</a> center who had failed to score a single point in one of their recent games. The quip inspired countless citations and references by announcers during those playoffs, though Dampier himself offered little response to the insult. The two would meet in the <a href="/wiki/2006_NBA_Finals" title="2006 NBA Finals">2006 NBA Finals</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">&#91;173&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>O'Neal was very vocal with the media, often making jabs at former Laker teammate Kobe Bryant. In the summer of 2005, when asked about Bryant, he responded, "I'm sorry, who?" and continued to pretend that he did not know who Bryant was until well into the 2005–06 season.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">&#91;174&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>O'Neal also appeared on television on <i><a href="/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live" title="Saturday Night Live">Saturday Night Live</a></i> (he was initially picked to host the second episode of season 24 in 1998, but had to back down due to scheduling conflicts, being replaced by <a href="/wiki/Kelsey_Grammer" title="Kelsey Grammer">Kelsey Grammer</a>; however, he did appear in two sketches during the episode) and in 2007 hosted <i>Shaq's Big Challenge</i>, a reality show on ABC in which he challenged Florida kids to lose weight and stay in shape.
</p><p>When the Lakers faced the Heat on January 16, 2006, O'Neal and Bryant made headlines by engaging in handshakes and hugs before the game, an event that was believed to signify the end of the so-called "<a href="/wiki/Bryant%E2%80%93O%27Neal_feud" class="mw-redirect" title="Bryant–O&#39;Neal feud">Bryant–O'Neal feud</a>" that had festered since O'Neal left Los Angeles. O'Neal was quoted as saying that he accepted the advice of NBA legend <a href="/wiki/Bill_Russell" title="Bill Russell">Bill Russell</a> to make peace with Bryant.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">&#91;175&#93;</a></sup> On June 22, 2008, O'Neal <a href="/wiki/Freestyle_rap" title="Freestyle rap">freestyled</a> a diss rap about Bryant in a New York club. While rapping, O'Neal blamed Bryant for his divorce from his wife Shaunie and claims to have received a <a href="/wiki/Vasectomy" title="Vasectomy">vasectomy</a>, as part of a rhyme. He also taunted Bryant for not being able to win a championship without him. O'Neal led the audience to mockingly chant several times "Kobe, tell me how my ass tastes".<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">&#91;176&#93;</a></sup> O'Neal justified his act by saying "I was freestyling. That's all. It was all done in fun. Nothing serious whatsoever. That is what MCs do. They freestyle when called upon. I'm totally cool with Kobe. No issue at all."<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">&#91;177&#93;</a></sup> Although even other exponents of <a href="/wiki/Hip_hop_music" title="Hip hop music">hip hop</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Snoop_Dogg" title="Snoop Dogg">Snoop Dogg</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nas" title="Nas">Nas</a> and Cory Gunz, agreed with O'Neal,<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">&#91;178&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Maricopa_County,_Arizona" title="Maricopa County, Arizona">Maricopa County</a>, Arizona Sheriff <a href="/wiki/Joe_Arpaio" title="Joe Arpaio">Joe Arpaio</a> expressed his intention to relieve O'Neal of his Maricopa County sheriff posse badge, due to "use of a racially derogatory word and other foul language". The racial quote from his song was "it's like a white boy trying to be more <a href="/wiki/Nigga" title="Nigga">nigga</a> than me."<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">&#91;179&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music_career">Music career</span></h3>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1126788409"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1066479718"><table class="infobox vcard plainlist"><tbody><tr><th colspan="2" class="infobox-above" style="background-color: #b0c4de; font-size: 125%;"><div class="fn">Shaquille O'Neal + DIESEL (DJ)</div></th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" class="infobox-image"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Shaq_2018_MLB_All-_Star_Weekend_Celebrity_Softball_(cropped).jpg" class="mw-file-description" title="DIESEL DJing at the 2018 All-Star Legends &amp; Celebrity Softball Game"><img alt="DIESEL DJing at the 2018 All-Star Legends &amp; Celebrity Softball Game" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Shaq_2018_MLB_All-_Star_Weekend_Celebrity_Softball_%28cropped%29.jpg/275px-Shaq_2018_MLB_All-_Star_Weekend_Celebrity_Softball_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="275" height="187" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Shaq_2018_MLB_All-_Star_Weekend_Celebrity_Softball_%28cropped%29.jpg/413px-Shaq_2018_MLB_All-_Star_Weekend_Celebrity_Softball_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Shaq_2018_MLB_All-_Star_Weekend_Celebrity_Softball_%28cropped%29.jpg/550px-Shaq_2018_MLB_All-_Star_Weekend_Celebrity_Softball_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2362" data-file-height="1604" /></a></span><div class="infobox-caption">DIESEL <a href="/wiki/DJing" class="mw-redirect" title="DJing">DJing</a> at the 2018 <a href="/wiki/All-Star_Legends_%26_Celebrity_Softball_Game" title="All-Star Legends &amp; Celebrity Softball Game">All-Star Legends &amp; Celebrity Softball Game</a></div></td></tr><tr><th colspan="2" class="infobox-header" style="background-color: #b0c4de">Background information</th></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Genres</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Hip_hop_music" title="Hip hop music">Hip hop</a>, <a href="/wiki/Electronic_dance_music" title="Electronic dance music">electronic dance music</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Occupation(s)</th><td class="infobox-data role"><a href="/wiki/Rapping" title="Rapping">Rapper</a>, <a href="/wiki/Disc_jockey" title="Disc jockey">DJ</a></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><span class="nowrap">Years active</span></th><td class="infobox-data">1993–2001; 2017–present</td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="infobox-label">Labels</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Jive_Records" title="Jive Records">Jive</a>, <a href="/wiki/Interscope_Records" title="Interscope Records">Interscope</a>, <a href="/wiki/A%26M_Records" title="A&amp;M Records">A&amp;M</a>, <a href="/wiki/Trauma_Records" title="Trauma Records">Trauma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Monstercat" title="Monstercat">Monstercat</a></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Beginning in 1993, O'Neal began to compose <a href="/wiki/Rap_music" class="mw-redirect" title="Rap music">rap music</a>. He released five studio albums and 1 <a href="/wiki/Compilation_album" title="Compilation album">compilation album</a>. Although his rapping abilities were criticized at the outset,<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">&#91;180&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">&#91;181&#93;</a></sup> one critic credited him with "progressing as a rapper in small steps, not leaps and bounds".<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">&#91;182&#93;</a></sup> His 1993 debut album, <i><a href="/wiki/Shaq_Diesel" title="Shaq Diesel">Shaq Diesel</a></i>, received <a href="/wiki/Music_recording_sales_certification" class="mw-redirect" title="Music recording sales certification">platinum certification</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Recording_Industry_Association_of_America" title="Recording Industry Association of America">RIAA</a>.
</p><p>O'Neal was featured alongside <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson" title="Michael Jackson">Michael Jackson</a> as a guest rapper on "2 Bad", a song from Jackson's 1995 album <i><a href="/wiki/HIStory:_Past,_Present_and_Future,_Book_I" title="HIStory: Past, Present and Future, Book I">HIStory</a></i>. He contributed three tracks, including the song "We Genie", to the <i><a href="/wiki/Kazaam" title="Kazaam">Kazaam</a></i> <a href="/wiki/Kazaam_(soundtrack)" title="Kazaam (soundtrack)">soundtrack</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-AllmusicReview_183-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AllmusicReview-183">&#91;183&#93;</a></sup> O'Neal was also featured in <a href="/wiki/Aaron_Carter" title="Aaron Carter">Aaron Carter</a>'s 2001 hit single "<a href="/wiki/That%27s_How_I_Beat_Shaq" title="That&#39;s How I Beat Shaq">That's How I Beat Shaq</a>". Shaq also appears in the music video for the release.<sup id="cite_ref-aaron_184-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aaron-184">&#91;184&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Shaquille O'Neal conducted the <a href="/wiki/Boston_Pops_Orchestra" title="Boston Pops Orchestra">Boston Pops Orchestra</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Boston_Symphony_Hall" class="mw-redirect" title="Boston Symphony Hall">Boston Symphony Hall</a> on December 20, 2010.
</p><p>O'Neal also started DJing in the 1980s at LSU.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">&#91;185&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="As_DJ_Diesel">As DJ Diesel</span></h4>
<p>Currently, O'Neal produces electronic dance music and tours the world under the stage name DJ Diesel.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">&#91;186&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In July 2017, O'Neal released a <a href="/wiki/Diss_track" class="mw-redirect" title="Diss track">diss track</a> aimed at <a href="/wiki/LaVar_Ball" title="LaVar Ball">LaVar Ball</a>, the father of NBA point guard <a href="/wiki/Lonzo_Ball" title="Lonzo Ball">Lonzo Ball</a>. The three-minute song was released in response to Ball claiming him and his younger son <a href="/wiki/LaMelo" class="mw-redirect" title="LaMelo">LaMelo</a>, would beat O'Neal and his son <a href="/wiki/Shareef_O%27Neal" title="Shareef O&#39;Neal">Shareef</a> in a game of basketball.
</p><p>On October 23, 2021, O'Neal performed his first ever set as DJ Diesel on the bassPOD stage at the 2021 <a href="/wiki/Electric_Daisy_Carnival" title="Electric Daisy Carnival">Electric Daisy Carnival</a> in <a href="/wiki/Las_Vegas,_Nevada" class="mw-redirect" title="Las Vegas, Nevada">Las Vegas, Nevada</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">&#91;187&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">&#91;188&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">&#91;189&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On June 7, 2023, O'Neal released his first single as DJ Diesel from his debut album <i>Gorilla Warfare</i>, titled "Bang Your Head" in collaboration with Hairitage.<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">&#91;190&#93;</a></sup> The album was released on August 18.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">&#91;191&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>
<p>O'Neal left LSU for the NBA after three years. However, he promised his mother he would eventually return to his studies and complete his <a href="/wiki/Bachelor%27s_degree" title="Bachelor&#39;s degree">bachelor's degree</a>. He fulfilled that promise in 2000, earning his <a href="/wiki/Bachelor_of_Arts" title="Bachelor of Arts">B.A.</a> degree in general studies from LSU,<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">&#91;192&#93;</a></sup> with a minor in <a href="/wiki/Political_science" title="Political science">political science</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">&#91;193&#93;</a></sup> Coach <a href="/wiki/Phil_Jackson" title="Phil Jackson">Phil Jackson</a> let O'Neal miss a home game so he could attend graduation. At the ceremony, he told the crowd "now I can go and get a real job".
Subsequently, O'Neal earned an online <a href="/wiki/Master_of_Business_Administration" title="Master of Business Administration">MBA</a> degree through the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Phoenix" title="University of Phoenix">University of Phoenix</a> in 2005. In reference to his completion of his MBA degree, he stated: "It's just something to have on my resume for when I go back into reality. Someday I might have to put down a basketball and have a regular 9-to-5 like everybody else."<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">&#91;194&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Toward the end of his playing career, he began work on an educational doctorate at <a href="/wiki/Barry_University" title="Barry University">Barry University</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-nytimes.com_195-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes.com-195">&#91;195&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">&#91;196&#93;</a></sup> His doctoral capstone<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">&#91;197&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">&#91;198&#93;</a></sup> topic was "The Duality of Humor and Aggression in Leadership Styles".<sup id="cite_ref-nytimes.com_195-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes.com-195">&#91;195&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">&#91;199&#93;</a></sup> O'Neal received his <a href="/wiki/Doctor_of_Education" title="Doctor of Education">Ed.D.</a> degree in <a href="/wiki/Human_Resource_Development" class="mw-redirect" title="Human Resource Development">Human Resource Development</a> from Barry in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">&#91;200&#93;</a></sup> O'Neal told a reporter for <a href="/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">ABC News</a> that he plans to further his education by attending law school.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">&#91;201&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2009, O'Neal attended the <a href="/wiki/Sportscaster_U." title="Sportscaster U.">Sportscaster U.</a> training camp at <a href="/wiki/S._I._Newhouse_School_of_Public_Communications" class="mw-redirect" title="S. I. Newhouse School of Public Communications">S. I. Newhouse School of Public Communications</a> at <a href="/wiki/Syracuse_University" title="Syracuse University">Syracuse University</a>, saying "You have to know what you’re doing... I needed to learn the secrets".<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">&#91;202&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">&#91;203&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>O'Neal has also studied directing and cinematography with the New York Film Academy's Filmmaking Conservatory.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">&#91;204&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_enforcement">Law enforcement</span></h3>
<p>O'Neal maintained a high level of interest in the workings of police departments and became personally involved in law enforcement. O'Neal went through the <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_County_Sheriff" class="mw-redirect" title="Los Angeles County Sheriff">Los Angeles County Sheriff</a>'s Reserve Academy and became a reserve officer with the <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Port_Police" title="Los Angeles Port Police">Los Angeles Port Police</a>. 
On March 2, 2005, O'Neal was given an honorary <a href="/wiki/United_States_Marshals_Service" title="United States Marshals Service">U.S. Deputy Marshal</a> title and named the spokesman for the Safe Surfin' Foundation; he served an honorary role on the task force of the same name, which tracks down <a href="/wiki/Sexual_predator" title="Sexual predator">sexual predators</a> who target children on the Internet.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">&#91;205&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Upon his trade to Miami, O'Neal began training to become a <a href="/wiki/Miami_Beach,_Florida" title="Miami Beach, Florida">Miami Beach</a> reserve officer. On December 8, 2005, he was sworn in, but elected for a private ceremony to avoid distracting attention from the other officers. He assumed a $1-per-year salary in this capacity.<sup id="cite_ref-policeoff_206-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-policeoff-206">&#91;206&#93;</a></sup> Shortly thereafter, in Miami, O'Neal witnessed a <a href="/wiki/Hate_crime" title="Hate crime">hate crime</a> (assaulting a man while calling out <a href="/wiki/Homophobic" class="mw-redirect" title="Homophobic">homophobic</a> slurs) and called Miami-Dade police, describing the suspect and helping police, over his cell phone, track the offender.<sup id="cite_ref-policeoff_206-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-policeoff-206">&#91;206&#93;</a></sup> O'Neal's actions resulted in the arrest of two suspects on charges of <a href="/wiki/Aggravated_battery" class="mw-redirect" title="Aggravated battery">aggravated battery</a>, assault, and a <a href="/wiki/Hate_crime" title="Hate crime">hate crime</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">&#91;207&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In September 2006, O'Neal took part in a raid on a home in rural <a href="/wiki/Bedford_County,_Virginia" title="Bedford County, Virginia">Bedford County, Virginia</a>. O'Neal had been made an "honorary deputy" by the local sheriff's department. O'Neal was not qualified as a SWAT officer.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">&#91;208&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In June 2008, the <a href="/wiki/Bedford_County,_Virginia" title="Bedford County, Virginia">Bedford County, Virginia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Maricopa_County,_Arizona" title="Maricopa County, Arizona">Maricopa County, Arizona</a>, sheriff departments revoked O'Neal's special deputyship after a video surfaced of him rapping about <a href="/wiki/Kobe_Bryant" title="Kobe Bryant">Kobe Bryant</a> and using racial slurs.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">&#91;209&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">&#91;210&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On January 20, 2015,  O'Neal was sworn in as a reserve officer for <a href="/wiki/Doral,_Florida" title="Doral, Florida">Doral, Florida</a>'s police force.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">&#91;211&#93;</a></sup> In December 2016, O'Neal was sworn in as a sheriff's deputy in <a href="/wiki/Jonesboro,_Georgia" title="Jonesboro, Georgia">Jonesboro, Georgia</a>, as part of <a href="/wiki/Clayton_County,_Georgia" title="Clayton County, Georgia">Clayton County, Georgia</a> Sheriff's Department. O'Neal holds the county record of Tallest Sheriff's Deputy.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">&#91;212&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Acting">Acting</span></h3>
<p>Starting with <i><a href="/wiki/Blue_Chips" title="Blue Chips">Blue Chips</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Kazaam" title="Kazaam">Kazaam</a></i>, O'Neal appeared in films that were panned by some critics.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">&#91;213&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">&#91;214&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>O'Neal is one of the first African Americans to portray a major comic book superhero in a motion picture, having starred as <a href="/wiki/Steel_(John_Henry_Irons)" title="Steel (John Henry Irons)">John Henry Irons</a>, the protagonist in the 1997 film <i><a href="/wiki/Steel_(1997_film)" title="Steel (1997 film)">Steel</a></i>. He is preceded only by <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jai_White" title="Michael Jai White">Michael Jai White</a>, whose film <i><a href="/wiki/Spawn_(1997_film)" title="Spawn (1997 film)">Spawn</a></i> was released two weeks before <i>Steel</i>.
</p><p>O'Neal appeared as himself on an episode of <i><a href="/wiki/Curb_Your_Enthusiasm" title="Curb Your Enthusiasm">Curb Your Enthusiasm</a></i>, bedridden after <a href="/wiki/Larry_David" title="Larry David">Larry David</a>'s character accidentally tripped him while stretching, and in two episodes each of <i><a href="/wiki/My_Wife_and_Kids" title="My Wife and Kids">My Wife and Kids</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Parkers" title="The Parkers">The Parkers</a></i>. He appeared in cameo roles in the films <i><a href="/wiki/Freddy_Got_Fingered" title="Freddy Got Fingered">Freddy Got Fingered</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Jack_and_Jill_(2011_film)" title="Jack and Jill (2011 film)">Jack and Jill</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Scary_Movie_4" title="Scary Movie 4">Scary Movie 4</a></i>. O'Neal appeared in the <a href="/wiki/311_(band)" title="311 (band)">311</a> music video for the hit single "<a href="/wiki/You_Wouldn%27t_Believe" title="You Wouldn&#39;t Believe">You Wouldn't Believe</a>" in 2001, in <a href="/wiki/Sean_Combs" title="Sean Combs">P. Diddy's</a> video for "<a href="/wiki/Bad_Boy_for_Life" title="Bad Boy for Life">Bad Boy for Life</a>", the video for <a href="/wiki/Aaron_Carter" title="Aaron Carter">Aaron Carter</a>'s "<a href="/wiki/That%27s_How_I_Beat_Shaq" title="That&#39;s How I Beat Shaq">That's How I Beat Shaq</a>", the video for <a href="/wiki/Owl_City" title="Owl City">Owl City</a>'s "<a href="/wiki/Vanilla_Twilight" title="Vanilla Twilight">Vanilla Twilight</a>" and the video for <a href="/wiki/Maroon_5" title="Maroon 5">Maroon 5</a>'s "<a href="/wiki/Don%27t_Wanna_Know" title="Don&#39;t Wanna Know">Don't Wanna Know</a>". O'Neal appeared in the movie <i><a href="/wiki/CB4" title="CB4">CB4</a></i> in a small "interviewing" scene. O'Neal appeared in a <i><a href="/wiki/SportsCenter" title="SportsCenter">SportsCenter</a></i> commercial dressed in his Miami police uniform, rescuing <a href="/wiki/Mike_the_Tiger" title="Mike the Tiger">Mike the Tiger</a> from a tree. O'Neal reportedly wanted a role in <i><a href="/wiki/X2_(film)" title="X2 (film)">X2</a></i> (2003), the second installment of the <a href="/wiki/X-Men_(film_series)" title="X-Men (film series)"><i>X-Men</i> film series</a>, but was ignored by the filmmakers.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">&#91;215&#93;</a></sup> O'Neal appeared as Officer Fluzoo in the comedy sequel <i><a href="/wiki/Grown_Ups_2" title="Grown Ups 2">Grown Ups 2</a></i>.
</p><p>He voiced animated versions of himself on several occasions, including in the animated series <i><a href="/wiki/Static_Shock" title="Static Shock">Static Shock</a></i> (2002; episode "Static Shaq"), in <i><a href="/wiki/Johnny_Bravo" title="Johnny Bravo">Johnny Bravo</a></i> (1997; episode "Back on Shaq"), in <i><a href="/wiki/Uncle_Grandpa" title="Uncle Grandpa">Uncle Grandpa</a></i> (2014; episode "Perfect Kid"), and in <i><a href="/wiki/The_Lego_Movie" title="The Lego Movie">The Lego Movie</a></i> (2014). He also had a voice over role in the 2013 film <i><a href="/wiki/The_Smurfs_2" title="The Smurfs 2">The Smurfs 2</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">&#91;216&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Video_games">Video games</span></h3>
<p>O'Neal was featured on the covers of video games <i><a href="/wiki/NBA_Live_96" title="NBA Live 96">NBA Live 96</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/NBA_2K6" title="NBA 2K6">NBA 2K6</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/NBA_2K7" title="NBA 2K7">NBA 2K7</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/NBA_Showtime:_NBA_on_NBC" title="NBA Showtime: NBA on NBC">NBA Showtime: NBA on NBC</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/NBA_Hoopz" title="NBA Hoopz">NBA Hoopz</a></i>, and <i>NBA Inside Drive 2004</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">&#91;217&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">&#91;218&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">&#91;219&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">&#91;220&#93;</a></sup> O'Neal appeared in the arcade version of <i><a href="/wiki/NBA_Jam_(1993_video_game)" title="NBA Jam (1993 video game)">NBA Jam</a></i> (1993), <i><a href="/wiki/NBA_Jam_(2003_video_game)" title="NBA Jam (2003 video game)">NBA Jam</a></i> (2003) and <i><a href="/wiki/NBA_Live_2004" title="NBA Live 2004">NBA Live 2004</a></i> as a current player and as a 1990s All-Star. O'Neal starred in <i><a href="/wiki/Shaq_Fu" title="Shaq Fu">Shaq Fu</a></i>, a fighting game for the <a href="/wiki/Super_Nintendo_Entertainment_System" title="Super Nintendo Entertainment System">Super Nintendo Entertainment System</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mega_Drive" class="mw-redirect" title="Mega Drive">Sega Genesis</a>. A sequel, <i><a href="/wiki/Shaq_Fu:_A_Legend_Reborn" title="Shaq Fu: A Legend Reborn">Shaq Fu: A Legend Reborn</a></i>, was released in 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">&#91;221&#93;</a></sup> O'Neal also appeared in <i><a href="/wiki/Quest_for_the_Code" title="Quest for the Code">Quest for the Code</a></i> in 2002 as a voice actor,<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">&#91;222&#93;</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Backyard_Sports_series" class="mw-redirect" title="Backyard Sports series">Backyard Basketball</a></i> in 2004, <i><a href="/wiki/Ready_2_Rumble_Boxing:_Round_2" title="Ready 2 Rumble Boxing: Round 2">Ready 2 Rumble Boxing: Round 2</a></i> as a playable boxer, and as an unlockable character in <i><a href="/wiki/Delta_Force:_Black_Hawk_Down" title="Delta Force: Black Hawk Down">Delta Force: Black Hawk Down</a></i>. O'Neal was also an unlockable character in <i><a href="/wiki/UFC_Undisputed_2010" title="UFC Undisputed 2010">UFC Undisputed 2010</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">&#91;223&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Television">Television</span></h3>
<p>O'Neal and his mother, Lucille Harrison, were featured in the documentary film <i>Apple Pie</i>, which aired on <a href="/wiki/ESPN" title="ESPN">ESPN</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">&#91;224&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">&#91;225&#93;</a></sup> O'Neal had a 2005 reality series on ESPN, <i><a href="/wiki/Shaquille_(TV_series)" title="Shaquille (TV series)">Shaquille</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">&#91;226&#93;</a></sup> and hosted a series called <i><a href="/wiki/Shaq%27s_Big_Challenge" title="Shaq&#39;s Big Challenge">Shaq's Big Challenge</a></i> on <a href="/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">ABC</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">&#91;227&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>O'Neal appeared on <i><a href="/wiki/NBA_Ballers" title="NBA Ballers">NBA Ballers</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/NBA_Ballers:_Phenom" title="NBA Ballers: Phenom">NBA Ballers: Phenom</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">&#91;228&#93;</a></sup> in the 2002 <a href="/wiki/Discovery_Channel" title="Discovery Channel">Discovery Channel</a> special <i>Motorcycle Mania 2</i> requesting an exceptionally large bike to fit his large size famed custom motorcycle builder <a href="/wiki/Jesse_James_(customizer)" class="mw-redirect" title="Jesse James (customizer)">Jesse James</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">&#91;229&#93;</a></sup> in the first <a href="/wiki/Idol_Gives_Back" title="Idol Gives Back">Idol Gives Back</a> in 2007,<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">&#91;230&#93;</a></sup> on an episode of <i><a href="/wiki/Fear_Factor" title="Fear Factor">Fear Factor</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">&#91;231&#93;</a></sup> and on an episode of MTV's <i><a href="/wiki/Jackass_(franchise)" title="Jackass (franchise)">Jackass</a></i>, where he was lifted off the ground on <a href="/wiki/Jason_Acu%C3%B1a" title="Jason Acuña">Wee Man</a>'s back.<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">&#91;232&#93;</a></sup> O'Neal was a wrestling fan and made appearances at many <a href="/wiki/World_Wrestling_Entertainment" class="mw-redirect" title="World Wrestling Entertainment">WWE</a> and <a href="/wiki/All_Elite_Wrestling" title="All Elite Wrestling">AEW</a> events.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">&#91;233&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>O'Neal was pranked on the MTV show <i><a href="/wiki/Punk%27d" title="Punk&#39;d">Punk'd</a></i> when a crew member accused him of stealing his parking space. After O'Neal and his wife went into a restaurant, <a href="/wiki/Ashton_Kutcher" title="Ashton Kutcher">Ashton Kutcher</a>'s crew members let the air out of O'Neal's tires. O'Neal and the crew member then got into an altercation and after Kutcher told O'Neal he had been Punk'd, O'Neal <a href="/wiki/Finger_(gesture)" class="mw-redirect" title="Finger (gesture)">made an obscene gesture</a> at the camera.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">&#91;234&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">&#91;235&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>O'Neal starred in a reality show called <i><a href="/wiki/Shaq_Vs." title="Shaq Vs.">Shaq Vs.</a></i> which premiered on August 18, 2009, on <a href="/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">ABC</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">&#91;236&#93;</a></sup> The show featured O'Neal competing against other athletes at their own sports.<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">&#91;237&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On July 14, 2011, O'Neal announced that he would join <a href="/wiki/Turner_Network_Television" class="mw-redirect" title="Turner Network Television">Turner Network Television</a> (TNT) as an analyst on its NBA basketball games, joining <a href="/wiki/Ernie_Johnson,_Jr." class="mw-redirect" title="Ernie Johnson, Jr.">Ernie Johnson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kenny_Smith" title="Kenny Smith">Kenny Smith</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Charles_Barkley" title="Charles Barkley">Charles Barkley</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">&#91;238&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>He hosted the show <i><a href="/wiki/Upload_with_Shaquille_O%27Neal" title="Upload with Shaquille O&#39;Neal">Upload with Shaquille O'Neal</a></i> which aired on <a href="/wiki/TruTV" title="TruTV">TruTV</a> for one season.
</p><p>In September 2015 whilst promoting sportswear giant <a href="/wiki/Reebok" title="Reebok">Reebok</a> in <a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">South Korea</a>, O'Neal joined the cast in the <a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">South Korean</a> variety television show <i><a href="/wiki/Off_to_School" class="mw-redirect" title="Off to School">Off to School</a></i> where he went to Seo Incheon High School. The show features various celebrities attending a selected high school as students for three days.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">&#91;239&#93;</a></sup> The producer of the show, Kim No-eun said, "We've worked hard on our guest list this season, so Chu Sung Hoon will be appearing on a cable channel for the first time. Shaquille O'Neal will be on the show as well. We succeeded in casting him after a lot of effort. O'Neal will be visiting Korea for a promotion and will be visiting the school on the last day. He will have lunch with the students. We're even preparing a big match between Chu Sung Hoon and Shaquille O'Neal. We're specially preparing a uniform for Shaquille O'Neal."<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">&#91;240&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">&#91;241&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">&#91;242&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In October 2022, O'Neal signed a long-term contract extension with <a href="/wiki/Warner_Bros._Discovery_Sports" title="Warner Bros. Discovery Sports">Warner Bros. Discovery Sports</a> to continue as a host on <i><a href="/wiki/Inside_the_NBA" title="Inside the NBA">Inside the NBA</a>.</i><sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">&#91;243&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Advertising">Advertising</span></h3>
<p>O'Neal has made numerous appearances in television commercials, including several <a href="/wiki/Pepsi" title="Pepsi">Pepsi</a> commercials, such as one from 1995 which parodied shows like <i><a href="/wiki/I_Love_Lucy" title="I Love Lucy">I Love Lucy</a></i> (the "Job Switching" episode), <i><a href="/wiki/Bonanza" title="Bonanza">Bonanza</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Woody_Woodpecker" title="Woody Woodpecker">Woody Woodpecker</a></i>. Other companies and products for which he has appeared in commercials include <a href="/wiki/Reebok" title="Reebok">Reebok</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nestl%C3%A9_Crunch" class="mw-redirect" title="Nestlé Crunch">Nestlé Crunch</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gold_Bond" title="Gold Bond">Gold Bond</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buick" title="Buick">Buick</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_General_(insurance)" title="The General (insurance)">The General</a>, <a href="/wiki/Papa_John%27s" title="Papa John&#39;s">Papa John's</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hulu" title="Hulu">Hulu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Epson" title="Epson">Epson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carnival_Cruise_Line" title="Carnival Cruise Line">Carnival Cruises</a>, <a href="/wiki/Frosted_Flakes" title="Frosted Flakes">Frosted Flakes</a>, <a href="/wiki/American_Express" title="American Express">American Express</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vitamin_Water" class="mw-redirect" title="Vitamin Water">Vitamin Water</a>, and <a href="/wiki/IcyHot" class="mw-redirect" title="IcyHot">IcyHot</a>, among others.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mixed_martial_arts">Mixed martial arts</span></h3>
<p>O'Neal began training in <a href="/wiki/Mixed_martial_arts" title="Mixed martial arts">mixed martial arts</a> (MMA) in 2000. At Jonathan Burke's Gracie Gym, he trained in <a href="/wiki/Boxing" title="Boxing">boxing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jujutsu" title="Jujutsu">jiu-jitsu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Muay_Thai" title="Muay Thai">Muay Thai</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wrestling" title="Wrestling">wrestling</a>. At the gym, he used the nickname Diesel.<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">&#91;244&#93;</a></sup> O'Neal challenged <a href="/wiki/Kickboxer" class="mw-redirect" title="Kickboxer">kickboxer</a> and mixed martial artist <a href="/wiki/Choi_Hong-man" class="mw-redirect" title="Choi Hong-man">Choi Hong-man</a> to a mixed martial arts rules bout in a YouTube video posted on June 17, 2009. Choi replied to an email asking him if he would like to fight O'Neal saying "Yes, if there is a chance." Hong-man also responded to a question asking if O'Neal had a chance of winning with a simple "No."<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">&#91;245&#93;</a></sup> On August 28, 2010, in an interview at <a href="/wiki/UFC_118" title="UFC 118">UFC 118</a> in Boston, O'Neal reiterated his desire to fight Choi.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">&#91;246&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Professional_wrestling">Professional wrestling</span></h3>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:WrestleMania_32_2016-04-03_21-21-03_ILCE-6000_0242_DxO_(27877585322).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/WrestleMania_32_2016-04-03_21-21-03_ILCE-6000_0242_DxO_%2827877585322%29.jpg/220px-WrestleMania_32_2016-04-03_21-21-03_ILCE-6000_0242_DxO_%2827877585322%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="391" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/WrestleMania_32_2016-04-03_21-21-03_ILCE-6000_0242_DxO_%2827877585322%29.jpg/330px-WrestleMania_32_2016-04-03_21-21-03_ILCE-6000_0242_DxO_%2827877585322%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/WrestleMania_32_2016-04-03_21-21-03_ILCE-6000_0242_DxO_%2827877585322%29.jpg/440px-WrestleMania_32_2016-04-03_21-21-03_ILCE-6000_0242_DxO_%2827877585322%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1604" data-file-height="2852" /></a><figcaption>O'Neal (left) facing <a href="/wiki/Big_Show" title="Big Show">Big Show</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9_the_Giant_Memorial_Battle_Royal" title="André the Giant Memorial Battle Royal">Andre The Giant Memorial Battle Royal</a> at <a href="/wiki/WrestleMania_32" title="WrestleMania 32">WrestleMania 32</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>A lifelong <a href="/wiki/Professional_wrestling" title="Professional wrestling">professional wrestling</a> fan, O'Neal has made numerous appearances at televised events over the years for four different promotions.<sup id="cite_ref-shaqaewdebut_247-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-shaqaewdebut-247">&#91;247&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">&#91;248&#93;</a></sup> His favorite wrestlers are <a href="/wiki/Tony_Atlas" title="Tony Atlas">Tony Atlas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Junkyard_Dog" title="Junkyard Dog">Junkyard Dog</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9_the_Giant" title="André the Giant">André the Giant</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Brock_Lesnar" title="Brock Lesnar">Brock Lesnar</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">&#91;249&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1994, O'Neal made several appearances in <a href="/wiki/World_Championship_Wrestling" title="World Championship Wrestling">World Championship Wrestling</a> (WCW), including at the <a href="/wiki/Bash_at_the_Beach_(1994)" title="Bash at the Beach (1994)">Bash at the Beach pay per view</a>, where he presented the title belt to the winner of the <a href="/wiki/WCW_World_Heavyweight_Championship" title="WCW World Heavyweight Championship">WCW World Heavyweight Championship</a> match between <a href="/wiki/Hulk_Hogan" title="Hulk Hogan">Hulk Hogan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ric_Flair" title="Ric Flair">Ric Flair</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">&#91;250&#93;</a></sup> In July 2009, O'Neal served as the guest host for a live broadcast of <a href="/wiki/WWE" title="WWE">WWE</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Monday_Night_Raw" class="mw-redirect" title="Monday Night Raw">Monday Night Raw</a></i>. As part of the show, O'Neal got into a physical altercation with seven-foot-tall wrestler <a href="/wiki/Big_Show" title="Big Show">Big Show</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">&#91;251&#93;</a></sup> In September 2012, O'Neal made a guest appearance on <a href="/wiki/Total_Nonstop_Action_Wrestling" class="mw-redirect" title="Total Nonstop Action Wrestling">Total Nonstop Action Wrestling</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Impact_Wrestling_(TV_series)" class="mw-redirect" title="Impact Wrestling (TV series)">Impact Wrestling</a></i> program, where he had a backstage segment with Hulk Hogan.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">&#91;252&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In April 2016, O'Neal participated in his first-ever match, when he was a surprise celebrity entry in the <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9_the_Giant" title="André the Giant">André the Giant</a> Memorial Battle Royal at <a href="/wiki/WrestleMania_32" title="WrestleMania 32">WrestleMania 32</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">&#91;253&#93;</a></sup> O'Neal eliminated <a href="/wiki/Damien_Sandow" class="mw-redirect" title="Damien Sandow">Damien Sandow</a>, and had another confrontation with Big Show before being eliminated himself by most of the other wrestlers.<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">&#91;254&#93;</a></sup> In July at the <a href="/wiki/2016_ESPY_Awards" title="2016 ESPY Awards">2016 ESPY Awards</a> on the red carpet, Big Show and O'Neal had another brief confrontation.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">&#91;255&#93;</a></sup> A match was proposed for <a href="/wiki/WrestleMania_33" title="WrestleMania 33">WrestleMania 33</a>, which O'Neal accepted.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">&#91;256&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">&#91;257&#93;</a></sup> In January 2017, the two began calling each other out on social media, posting workout videos of themselves preparing for the potential match.<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">&#91;258&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">&#91;259&#93;</a></sup> After weeks of discussion, the match was cancelled. According to <a href="/wiki/Dave_Meltzer" title="Dave Meltzer">Dave Meltzer</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/Wrestling_Observer_Newsletter" title="Wrestling Observer Newsletter">Wrestling Observer Newsletter</a></i>, the match was canceled due to monetary reasons, as both parties could not agree on a deal.<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">&#91;260&#93;</a></sup> Big Show later stated it was scheduling issues on O'Neal's part that caused the cancellation.<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">&#91;261&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On the November 11, 2020 episode of <i><a href="/wiki/AEW_Dynamite" title="AEW Dynamite">AEW Dynamite</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Jade_Cargill" title="Jade Cargill">Jade Cargill</a> interrupted <a href="/wiki/Cody_Rhodes" title="Cody Rhodes">Cody Rhodes</a> and teased the arrival of O'Neal in <a href="/wiki/All_Elite_Wrestling" title="All Elite Wrestling">All Elite Wrestling</a> (AEW).<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">&#91;262&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">&#91;263&#93;</a></sup> He made a cameo appearance on <i><a href="/wiki/Being_The_Elite" class="mw-redirect" title="Being The Elite">Being The Elite</a></i> and it was later confirmed that O'Neal had been appearing backstage at recent AEW tapings, including <a href="/wiki/Full_Gear_(2020)" title="Full Gear (2020)">Full Gear</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">&#91;264&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">&#91;265&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">&#91;266&#93;</a></sup> He appeared on the December 9 episode of <i>AEW Dynamite</i> and addressed AEW in a sit-down interview with <a href="/wiki/Tony_Schiavone" title="Tony Schiavone">Tony Schiavone</a> and <a href="/wiki/Brandi_Rhodes" title="Brandi Rhodes">Brandi Rhodes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">&#91;267&#93;</a></sup> At the end of the interview, O'Neal got water thrown on him by Brandi after telling her to get pointers from Cargill, who had broken Brandi's arm several weeks ago.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">&#91;268&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">&#91;269&#93;</a></sup> On the March 3, 2021 episode of <i>AEW Dynamite</i> titled <a href="/wiki/List_of_AEW_Dynamite_special_episodes" title="List of AEW Dynamite special episodes">The Crossroads</a>, O'Neal teamed with <a href="/wiki/Jade_Cargill" title="Jade Cargill">Jade Cargill</a> to defeat <a href="/wiki/Cody_Rhodes" title="Cody Rhodes">Cody Rhodes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Red_Velvet_(wrestler)" title="Red Velvet (wrestler)">Red Velvet</a>. During the match, O'Neal paid tribute to <a href="/wiki/Brodie_Lee" title="Brodie Lee">Brodie Lee</a> with his signature gesture and powerbomb and was driven through two tables by Cody, who hit O'Neal with a flying crossbody tackle as O'Neal was standing on the ring apron, knocking O'Neal through the tables that were set up at ringside.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">&#91;270&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">&#91;271&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Business_ventures">Business ventures</span></h3>
<p>As of 2022<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Shaquille_O%27Neal&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup> O'Neal is among the five wealthiest NBA players, with a net worth of $400 million.<sup id="cite_ref-hernandez20220623_272-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hernandez20220623-272">&#91;272&#93;</a></sup> He was an active bond investor in the early 1990s but continued to wade into stocks and made investments in various companies such as <a href="/wiki/General_Electric" title="General Electric">General Electric</a>, <a href="/wiki/Apple_Inc." title="Apple Inc.">Apple</a>, and <a href="/wiki/PepsiCo" title="PepsiCo">PepsiCo</a>. He described what has worked best for him in stock investing was where he felt a personal connection with the company.<sup id="cite_ref-TELIS_DEMOS_273-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TELIS_DEMOS-273">&#91;273&#93;</a></sup> O'Neal refused to endorse <a href="/wiki/Wheaties" title="Wheaties">Wheaties</a> cereal because he preferred <a href="/wiki/Frosted_Flakes" title="Frosted Flakes">Frosted Flakes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-hernandez20220623_272-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hernandez20220623-272">&#91;272&#93;</a></sup> He has also been an active <a href="/wiki/Real_estate_entrepreneur" class="mw-redirect" title="Real estate entrepreneur">real estate entrepreneur</a>. O'Neal was looking to expand his business ventures with real-estate development projects aimed at assisting <a href="/wiki/Orlando,_Florida" title="Orlando, Florida">Orlando</a> home owners facing <a href="/wiki/Foreclosure" title="Foreclosure">foreclosure</a>. His plans involved buying the <a href="/wiki/Mortgage_loan" title="Mortgage loan">mortgages</a> of those who had fallen into foreclosure and then selling the homes back to them under more affordable terms. He would make a small profit in return, but wanted to make an investment in Orlando and help out homeowners.<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">&#91;274&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In conjunction with Boraie Development, O'Neal has developed projects in his hometown of <a href="/wiki/Newark,_New_Jersey" title="Newark, New Jersey">Newark, New Jersey</a>, including, CityPlex12 and <a href="/wiki/One_Riverview_(Newark)" class="mw-redirect" title="One Riverview (Newark)">One Riverview</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">&#91;275&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">&#91;276&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">&#91;277&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">&#91;278&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">&#91;279&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>O'Neal is on the <a href="/wiki/Advisory_board" title="Advisory board">advisory board</a> for <a href="/wiki/Tout_(company)" title="Tout (company)">Tout Industries</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Social_media" title="Social media">social</a> video service <a href="/wiki/Startup_company" title="Startup company">startup company</a> based in San Francisco.<sup id="cite_ref-giles_133-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-giles-133">&#91;133&#93;</a></sup> He received the position in return for breaking news of his NBA retirement on the service.<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">&#91;280&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In September 2013, O'Neal became a minority owner of the <a href="/wiki/Sacramento_Kings" title="Sacramento Kings">Sacramento Kings</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">&#91;281&#93;</a></sup> In January 2022, O'Neal sold his stake in the Kings.<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">&#91;282&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>O'Neal was an early investor in <a href="/wiki/Google" title="Google">Google</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-hernandez20220623_272-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hernandez20220623-272">&#91;272&#93;</a></sup> In June 2015, he invested in technology startup Loyale3 Holdings Inc., a San Francisco brokerage firm whose website and mobile app enables companies to sell a piece of their <a href="/wiki/Initial_public_offering" title="Initial public offering">IPOs</a> directly to small investors who put up as a little as $100 and also allows investors to regularly buy small amounts of shares in already public companies.<sup id="cite_ref-TELIS_DEMOS_273-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TELIS_DEMOS-273">&#91;273&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>O'Neal is an investor for <a href="/wiki/Esports" title="Esports">esports</a> team <a href="/wiki/NRG_Esports" title="NRG Esports">NRG Esports</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">&#91;283&#93;</a></sup> He has also appeared in television commercials promoting the <i><a href="/wiki/Counter-Strike:_Global_Offensive" title="Counter-Strike: Global Offensive">Counter-Strike: Global Offensive</a></i> league <i><a href="/wiki/ELeague" title="ELeague">ELeague</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">&#91;284&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>O'Neal favors <a href="/wiki/Franchising" title="Franchising">franchising</a> businesses because of their simplicity and proven success.<sup id="cite_ref-hernandez20220623_272-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hernandez20220623-272">&#91;272&#93;</a></sup> In late 2016, he purchased the <a href="/wiki/Krispy_Kreme" title="Krispy Kreme">Krispy Kreme</a> location at 295 <a href="/wiki/Ponce_de_Leon_Avenue" title="Ponce de Leon Avenue">Ponce de Leon Avenue</a> in <a href="/wiki/Atlanta" title="Atlanta">Atlanta</a>. O'Neal is also the global spokesperson for the company.<sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">&#91;285&#93;</a></sup> He has owned and sold 155 <a href="/wiki/Five_Guys" title="Five Guys">Five Guys</a> restaurants—about 10% of all locations—and owns 17 <a href="/wiki/Auntie_Anne%27s" title="Auntie Anne&#39;s">Auntie Anne's</a> restaurants. O'Neal also owns 150 <a href="/wiki/Car_wash" title="Car wash">car washes</a>, 40 <a href="/wiki/Health_club" title="Health club">health clubs</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Big_Chicken_(restaurant_chain)" title="Big Chicken (restaurant chain)">Big Chicken</a> brand of <a href="/wiki/Chicken_sandwich" title="Chicken sandwich">chicken sandwiches</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-hernandez20220623_272-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hernandez20220623-272">&#91;272&#93;</a></sup>
